intro: Atriplex paludosa var. appendiculata, commonly known as the marsh saltbush, is a flowering plant native to wetland and coastal areas of North America. It is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves that help it retain moisture in saline or waterlogged soils. The plant produces small, greenish flowers arranged in dense clusters, which are typically wind-pollinated. Its salt tolerance makes it an important species in stabilizing coastal and marsh ecosystems. It is often found in association with other halophytes, contributing to the biodiversity of wetland habitats.
